choices.text: Visible deformity at the fracture site
Mobility at the middle of the shaft of the tibia.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient is brought to a hospital after he met with a road traffic accident. An orthopaedician examines him and explains that he has a fracture in his left leg before ordering any radiographs. From which of the following clinical findings was he able to make the diagnosis with certainty?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • Abnormal mobility is the Pathognomonic sign of a fracture. This finding is present only in the setting of a fracture.
  • Not every fracture is always associated with mobility; for example, a unicortical fracture, a stress fracture, a torus fracture, or a greenstick fracture.
  • So it is not a sensitive sign for fracture diagnosis, but it is the most specific sign for a fracture.

Explanation of other options:

Swelling (Option A) can be caused by either soft tissue or bony injury, so if swelling is present, we cannot determine whether it is a fracture or a soft tissue injury. Swelling may also be due to any tumour or any soft tissue disorder, so swelling is not the surest sign of a fracture.

Tenderness(Option B) may be there in soft tissue injury or fracture. It is also there in an infective collection or tumour, so tenderness is also not the surest sign of fracture.

Deformity(Option C) suggests fracture, but may also occur in longstanding malunions or congenital abnormalities. Not all fractures present with visible deformity, and its presence supports but does not confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with a history of deformity and abnormal mobility in his right upper arm, persisting for several months following an injury. On clinical examination, there is visible angulation and abnormal movement at the mid-shaft of the humerus, but the patient does not report any significant pain at the site.
Which of the following findings would most reliably help differentiate this chronic condition from a fresh fracture of the humeral shaft?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In fresh fractures, tenderness is invariably present due to acute inflammation and periosteal irritation.
  • However, in most cases of non-union, especially hypertrophic or atrophic types, pain and tenderness diminish over time. This is because the fracture becomes chronic and may even become symptomless.
  • Some mobile non-unions form pseudarthroses that can move freely but are painless, thus tenderness becomes a key differentiator.

Explanation of other options:

Swelling (Option A): Present in both fresh fractures (due to trauma) and sometimes in non-unions (due to repetitive microtrauma or callus). It is not specific.

Deformity (Option B): Seen in both fresh displaced fractures and longstanding non-unions, especially with malalignment. Not a reliable differentiating feature.

Mobility (Option D): Abnormal mobility is a hallmark of non-union (especially mobile types) but may also be present in fresh fractures, depending on the location and severity. Hence, not exclusive to one.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female gives a history of a fall while dancing, resulting in a twisting injury of the leg. What would be the expected pattern of fracture in a radiograph?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The following are the mechanisms of various patterns of fractures.
    • Tension-transverse fracture (Option A ruled out)
    • Bending-transverse butterfly fracture or green stick fracture (Option C ruled out)
    • Torsion-spiral oblique (seen in dancers)
    • Compression - short oblique
    • High-energy trauma/crush injuries-comminuted fracture. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: 8 year 8-year-old boy comes to the trauma centre with swelling and pain in his right forearm after a fall while playing. His radiograph is given below. What would be the suspected mechanism of his injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The above X-ray is suggestive of a greenstick fracture.
  • Greenstick fractures are unicortical fractures of long bones seen in children.
  • Green stick fractures are produced due to a bending

Explanation of other options:

Torsion (Option B): Causes spiral fractures, not greenstick types.

Direct impact (Option C): Usually leads to transverse or comminuted fractures.

Compression (Option D): More commonly results in short oblique fractures or impacted fractures, especially in the vertebrae or metaphyseal regions.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male is brought to the casualty with a history of RTA. He has sustained an open fracture of the femur, as shown in the X-ray below. On examination, there is an 8 cm lacerated wound above the popliteal fossa and absent popliteal and posterior tibial pulses. What is the Gustilo Anderson classification of the fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In this case, there is an open fracture of the femur with associated vascular injury. Vascular injury with open wound fracture is considered a grade 3C injury irrespective of wound size.

Gustilo: Anderson Classification of Open Fractures

questions.text: A patient has a closed multi-fragmentary fracture of the upper tibia with extensive contusion below the knee. The intracompartmental pressure of the posterior compartment of the leg is 35 mmHg. Classify the fracture.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Tscherne's classification deals with closed fractures with significant soft tissue contusions, even though there is no open wound.
  • A compartment pressure more than 30 mmHg is considered compartment syndrome, and a severe fracture pattern with compartment syndrome is considered a grade-3

Oestern and Tscherne Classification of Closed Fractures

questions.text: An army recruit with a smoking addiction has had pain in his right foot for the last 3 months after he started training. He has point tenderness and pain in the forefoot, which is aggravated by activity. What would be the clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • A stress fracture occurs due to abnormal loading of a normal bone.
  • The most common site of stress fracture is the Tibia, followed by the 2nd metatarsal (March Fracture)
  • The clinical hallmark is the insidious onset of pain, worsened by activity and relieved by rest, with localised tenderness.
  • A stress fracture is sometimes not seen on X-ray in the early stages. Hence, we need further investigations to confirm our diagnosis.
  • For a suspected stress fracture in one site, the investigation of choice is MRI.
  • But for bilateral stress fractures or multiple stress fractures, a bone scan is recommended over MRI as it is easy, effective and economical.

Explanation of other options:

Pathological fracture (Option A): Usually associated with underlying bone disease, systemic symptoms, or minimal trauma history.

Malignant lesion (Option C): Typically associated with persistent, deep, dull pain, constitutional symptoms, and may not follow mechanical activity patterns.

Infection (Option D): Often presents with fever, warmth, swelling, and may progress rapidly.

questions.text: An athlete who has been training constantly for 6 months for the upcoming national selections has pain over the posteromedial aspect of the right leg. He has point tenderness on the posteromedial aspect of the mid tibia, and the pain is aggravated by activity. What is the treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • From the history, the patient has typical features of a tibial stress fracture.
  • Stress fractures are generally managed conservatively with cast immobilisation.
  • An exception is a stress fracture of the neck of the femur, which might require surgical fixation.

Explanation of other options:

Intramedullary nailing (Option A): Not first-line for stress fractures unless there is non-union, or if it's a high-risk location like the anterior tibial cortex.

ORIF with distal tibia plate (Option B): Reserved for traumatic or displaced fractures, not used for stress injuries.

Rest and analgesics (Option D): Beneficial in early cases, but cast immobilisation is more appropriate when symptoms persist or are activity-limiting.

questions.text: 38 year 38-year-old lady was brought to the casualty with a sudden onset of back pain after she tried to lift a heavy box. She had a history of breast carcinoma, which was treated with surgery and chemotherapy 7 years ago. On examination, there is tenderness in the dorsolumbar area. X-ray shows collapse of T-12 vertebra. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Here patient has a collapse of T-12, indicating a fracture.
  • Such vertebral collapse with trivial injury is seen when there is a metastatic lesion on the vertebra, which in this case has come from Ca breast.
  • Such fractures occurring in a bone already weakened by an underlying disease are called Pathological fractures.

Explanation of other options:

Infective spondylodiscitis (Option A) generally has a history of fever, weight loss and constitutional symptoms, which are absent in this case.

Spondylolisthesis (Option B): Here, the patient has sudden onset pain, which is not the case in spondylolisthesis in where the patient has chronic back pain with radiation to lower limbs.

Osteoporotic fracture (Option D) Patient is 38 years old. At this age, osteoporosis is rare. Osteoporosis is common in elderly and post-menopausal females.

questions.text: 63 year 63-year-old female presents with severe hip pain without any history of trauma. Her X-ray shows a lytic lesion of around 7cm in the peritrochantric area of the right femur. What should be the management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • This patient has a large lytic lesion in the proximal femur.
  • As the lesion is in a weight-bearing area, there is a high risk of a pathological fracture occurring there.
  • In order to prevent this, we must perform prophylactic fixation of the bone.
  • In prophylactic fixation, we fix a bone without a fracture to prevent a fracture, preserve function, and avoid the morbidity associated with fracture repair or amputation.
  • The decision as to whether we need to fix a bone with a lytic lesion is made with the help of MIREL's score.

Mirel's Score

Explanation of Other Options:

Extended curettage with bone grafting (Option A): This is appropriate for benign lesions with a low risk of fracture, not applicable in potentially malignant or extensive lesions in critical locations.

Simple curettage (Option B): Insufficient for a large, structurally compromising lesion in the femur. Also does not provide mechanical support.

Amputation (Option D): Reserved for extensive malignant lesions or when limb salvage is not feasible, not indicated here as first-line.

questions.text: The commonest cause of pathological fracture worldwide is?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disorder characterised by low bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration, leading to increased bone fragility, particularly affecting the elderly population and postmenopausal women.
  • Pathological fractures, particularly in the hip, spine, and wrist, are hallmark complications of osteoporosis.
  • These fractures occur with minimal or no trauma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Osteopetrosis (Option A): Rare inherited condition causing abnormally dense but brittle bones. Not a common cause.

Stress fracture (Option B): These are fatigue fractures, not strictly classified as pathological fractures unless associated with underlying pathology.

Osteogenesis imperfecta (Option D): A rare congenital condition causing bone fragility, but not the most common cause globally.

choices.text: Patient-1 will have a delayed union compared to patient-2
Patient-2 will have a delayed union compared to patient-1
Both fractures will unite at the same time

questions.text: In comparison of two patients, Patient-1 is a 34-year-old female with a pathological fracture of the shaft of the femur due to metastasis of breast cancer, and Patient-2 is a 64-year-old female with a pathological fracture of the shaft femur due to osteoporosis. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Osteoporotic fractures occur in structurally weakened bone, but the underlying biological environment for healing is preserved, so union generally occurs, though it may be slightly prolonged.
  • In contrast, metastatic fractures occur in bone that is not only structurally compromised but also biologically altered due to tumour infiltration, poor vascularity, and often ongoing chemotherapy or radiotherapy, all of which impair healing.
  • Therefore, union is either significantly delayed or may not occur at all without surgical stabilisation or adjuvant therapy.

(Options B, C and D ruled out)

choices.text: Getting the patient to the operating theatre within 6 hours

questions.text: Which of the following emergency treatment measures is most important in preventing infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Factors for preventing postoperative infection in the case of an open fracture

  1. Proper surgical debridement
  2. Duration of surgery from the time of injury
  3. Proper saline wash during and before surgery
  4. Proper antibiotic coverage
  5. Mechanism of injury and severity of soft tissue injury
  6. Type of wound
  7. Postoperative dressing and its material

Explanation of other options:

Theatre within 6 hours (Option A): Known as the "golden period", but timing is secondary to the quality of debridement. Even if done slightly later, proper debridement is still key.

Wound irrigation (Option C): Important adjunct, particularly with normal saline, but not a substitute for mechanical debridement.

Delayed antibiotics (Option D): Delaying antibiotics increases infection risk; early antibiotics are important, but alone are insufficient without debridement.

questions.text: What is the best reduction technique for this fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Based on the X-ray provided, the fracture is a complex intra-articular distal femur fracture with comminution and metaphyseal extension.
  • Articular fracture requires perfect anatomical reduction with absolute stability, which requires direct reduction (Involves exposing the fracture site and manipulating the bone fragments directly under visualisation to restore anatomy).
  • Metaphysio-diaphyseal fracture requires functional reduction with relative stability.
  • Since this metaphyseal fracture is multifragmentary, it is better to do indirect reduction(re-aligning the fracture without directly opening or touching the fracture site, relying on the surrounding ligaments, periosteum, and soft tissues), as direct reduction of all the small fragments will result in loss of their blood supply.

(Options B, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: If this closed injury is treated with immediate internal fixation, what complication is most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In high-energy fractures with severe comminution, even when the skin is intact, there is often extensive underlying soft tissue damage. Immediate open internal fixation, especially through a swollen, contused limb, risks:
    • Soft tissue compromise,
    • Poor wound healing,
    • Skin necrosis and ultimately,
    • Wound breakdown.
  • This is particularly relevant in the distal femur, where the soft tissue envelope is not generous and can be easily compromised.

Explanation of other options:

Malunion (Option A): More likely if reduction or fixation is inadequate-not the primary concern with immediate fixation.

Compartment syndrome (Option B): More associated with tibial shaft fractures, and while possible, less likely here.

Post-traumatic arthritis (Option D): A long-term complication, especially with intra-articular extension, but not the immediate surgical concern.

questions.text: Interfragmentary screw and neutralizing plate acts on principle of _____, which results in_____ type of fracture healing.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Interfragmentary compression screws and neutralisation plates are used to achieve anatomical reduction and eliminate motion at the fracture site.
  • This results in absolute stability, which permits direct bone healing without callus formation, known as primary fracture healing.

Primary healing (contact or gap healing):

  • Occurs only when there is rigid internal fixation.
  • Bone remodelling happens through the Haversian system, cutting cones crossing the fracture site.

(Options A, C and D ruled out)

choices.text: An intramedullary nail in a comminuted diaphyseal fracture gives relative stability and heals by secondary healing with callus formation.
Bridge plate in comminuted diaphyseal fracture gives relative stability and heals by secondary healing with callus formation.
Neutralisation plate with intrafragmentary screw in a simple diaphyseal fracture gives absolute stability and heals by primary bone healing without callus formation
Bridge plate in comminuted diaphyseal fracture gives absolute stability and heals by primary bone healing without callus formation

questions.text: Which of following statement is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Bridge plating is used for comminuted fractures where the fracture fragments are not anatomically reduced but bridged by the plate.
  • It provides relative stability, allowing micromotion at the fracture site.
  • This promotes secondary bone healing with callus formation, not primary healing.
  • Intramedullary nailing in a comminuted diaphyseal fracture provides relative stability, leading to callus-based secondary healing. (Option A)
  • Bridge plating behaves similarly, offering relative stability with indirect bone healing. (Option B)
  • A neutralisation plate with an interfragmentary screw creates absolute stability, enabling direct bone healing without callus (primary healing). (Option C)

choices.text: Patient with a fractured arm with a 10cm long laceration over the arm
Patient with a fractured arm with a capillary refill time of 7 seconds in his fingers.
Patient with a closed fractured arm with a capillary refill time of less than 3 seconds in his fingers.

questions.text: You are the intern on duty, and you receive a patient who has been in a road traffic accident. For which of the following patients will you urgently call the orthopaedic resident on call?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Capillary refill time (CRT) > 2 seconds is a marker of vascular compromise.
  • A CRT of 7 seconds in the setting of a fractured arm is an orthopaedic emergency suggesting arterial insufficiency, possibly due to arterial injury, entrapment, or compartment syndrome.
  • This requires immediate orthopaedic (and possibly vascular) intervention to restore perfusion and prevent irreversible ischemia or limb loss.
  • Sequence of consideration of emergency in orthopaedic set-up:
    1. Vascular injury
    2. Nerve injury
    3. Open fracture
    4. Traumatic primary Joint dislocation
    5. Closed fracture

Explanation of other options:

Patient with a fractured arm with a 10cm long laceration over the arm (Option A): Suggestive of an open fracture, which should be operated on in an emergency, but a patient with vascular injury is considered a priority over an open fracture.

Recurrent shoulder dislocation (Option C) is non-urgent unless associated with neurovascular injury or locked dislocation.

Closed fracture with normal CRT (<3 seconds) (Option D) suggests adequate distal perfusion and does not require immediate referral unless there are other red flags.

choices.text: Closed fracture of the upper tibia with compartment syndrome and blisters over the skin
Closed fracture shaft humerus with Radial nerve palsy
Fracture with a burn wound over the fracture site

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of external fixator?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • A closed fracture of the humerus with radial nerve palsy is not an indication for external fixation.
  • Radial nerve palsy in this setting is typically managed conservatively, and the fracture is usually stabilised with internal fixation (e.g., plating or nailing) if needed.
  • External fixation is rarely, if ever, used for humeral shaft fractures unless severe soft tissue injury or infection precludes internal fixation.

Indications of the external fixator

  1. Open fracture (grade 3b-3c: absolute indication, grade 2-3a:relative indication) (Option A ruled out)
  2. Vascular injury(Option B ruled out)
  3. Severe soft tissue injury, like (Option C ruled out)
  4. Damage control orthopaedics
    • Nerve injury is not an indication of external fixation

choices.text: Traction until the patient gets stabilised
External fixator until the patient gets stabilised

questions.text: 42-year-old male with a history of RTA presented with a closed fracture shaft of the left femur with normal distal pulsations. He also has blunt chest trauma with minimal hemothorax with a GCS of 8. What should be your emergency treatment modality for orthopaedic injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • GCS-8 is considered a severe head injury. So patient has a severe head and chest injury, which requires resuscitation of patient.
  • Life is considered a priority over limbs. So, as damage control orthopaedics (DCO) must be done.
  • In DCO, we apply an external fixator for stabilising a fracture, under regional anaesthesia, as fast as possible.
  • This is done so that the patient's fracture remains stable for the time being, when more serious issues of head injury and chest injury can be managed.
  • Once those serious injuries are managed and the patient is medically fit, the external fixator is removed, and internal fixation is done as a second-stage procedure.

Explanation of other options:

Intramedullary nailing (Option A): Delayed definitive fixation, not suitable in an initial unstable setting.

Traction until stabilised (Option B): Used in some centres but inferior to external fixation in terms of mobility, pain control, and ease of ICU care.

Closed reduction and cast application (Option D): Not applicable to femoral shaft fractures in adults, not a feasible or stable option.

questions.text: All of the following is used for giving skeletal traction except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The Rush pin is used for pediatric diaphyseal fracture fixation.
  • All other devices: Steinmann's pin, Kirschner's wire and Bohler's stirrup are used for giving traction. (Options B, C and D ruled out).

Kirschner's wire

Bohler's stirrup

questions.text: The recommended rate of distraction of an Ilizarov external fixator:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Illizarov external fixator distraction is 25mm every 6 hours, so it sums up to 1mm per day
  • More than 1mm per day leads to a defect in the bone
  • Less than 1mm per day leads to early bone maturity.

Ilizarov external fixator

questions.text: Open fracture in a child of 2 1/2 years is managed by?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In children, most fractures heal well with conservative management due to the excellent healing and remodelling potential of the pediatric skeleton.

For open fractures, however, the first and most critical step is thorough surgical debridement to:

  • Remove all devitalized tissue and contaminants
  • Reduce risk of infection
  • Convert an open injury into a clean wound for further fracture management.

Explanation of other options:

External fixator (Option A): Used in high-grade open fractures, segmental injuries, or when there's significant soft tissue damage, not routine for a toddler with a standard open fracture.

Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) (Option C): Avoided in most paediatric fractures unless necessary due to growth plate injury risk and need to avoid hardware in developing bones.

Intramedullary nailing (Option D): More appropriate for older children (>5-6 years) or unstable femur fractures, not standard in a 2 1/2-year-old child.

choices.text: All fractures heal with callus formation
All intra-articular fracture requires anatomical reduction
Relative stability involves restoring length, rotation and alignment
Fracture healing requires the combined activity of osteoblast and osteoclast cells

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Not all fractures heal with callus formation.

  • Fractures that are treated with absolute stability, such as those managed with interfragmentary compression and rigid fixation, undergo primary (direct) bone healing, which occurs without callus formation.
  • Callus formation is characteristic of secondary bone healing, which occurs in cases of relative stability (e.g., casting, intramedullary nailing, bridge plating).

Explanation of other options:

All intra-articular fractures require anatomical reduction (Option B): To prevent joint incongruity and post-traumatic arthritis, intra-articular fractures should be anatomically reduced and fixed with absolute stability.

Relative stability involves restoring length, rotation and alignment (Option C): Even without a perfect anatomic reduction of fragments, relative stability aims to restore overall alignment, which is essential for function and healing.

Fracture healing requires the combined activity of osteoblast and osteoclast cells (Option D): Osteoblasts form new bone, and Osteoclasts remodel bone by resorbing old or damaged tissue.

choices.text: Closed reduction and intramedullary reamed nail

questions.text: A patient presents with a 10-day-old Grade 3A open fracture of the shaft of the tibia, complicated by pus discharge from the wound site. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The presence of pus discharge indicates established infection, making this a case of an infected open fracture.
  • In infected Grade 3 open fractures, internal fixation (ORIF or reamed nailing) is contraindicated until infection is controlled.
  • The priority is:
    • Surgical debridement to remove necrotic tissue and control infection.
    • Temporary or definitive external fixation to stabilise the fracture without introducing internal hardware that can harbour infection.

Explanation of other options:

Open reduction with internal fixation (Option A): Not advised in the presence of infection, increases the risk of chronic osteomyelitis.

Closed reduction with reamed nail (Option B): Reaming and internal nailing in infected bone is contraindicated.

Debridement with bone grafting (Option D): Bone grafting is never done in the presence of active infection; it is planned after infection has resolved.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female with 2 months of amenorrhea presents with a mid-clavicle fracture. What is your treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The midshaft clavicle fracture is one of the most common fractures, and most cases are managed conservatively.
  • In pregnancy, the general principle is to avoid surgical intervention unless necessary, due to:
    • Risks associated with anaesthesia and radiation exposure to the fetus.
    • Higher risk of thrombosis and complications.
  • A Figure-of-8 brace provides adequate immobilisation for most displaced or undisplaced midshaft clavicle fractures in pregnant patients and promotes natural healing.

Explanation of other options:

Open reduction and internal fixation (Option A): Generally reserved for severely displaced or open fractures or neurovascular compromise, avoided in pregnancy unless indicated.

Clavicular nail (Option C): Though less invasive, it still involves anaesthesia and fluoroscopy, which are best avoided in early pregnancy.

Closed reduction and internal fixation (Option D): Not the standard practice for clavicle fractures; plus, the fixation still carries the same concerns as ORIF.
